Here's an underway story that might spark your interest. Underway in the North Atlantic above the Arctic Circle, our coffee machines kept overflowing and wouldn't make coffee. NOT GOOD onboard a sub. After many days of trying to figure out why they wouldn't shut off when they were filling, it was discovered that the fresh water being distilled by the 10k/day still was so pure from the arctic waters, that the machine could not detect whether there was water in it or not. No electrolysis in the water. So, whoever got the empty pot and had to make a new one (boat policy), a pinch of salt was added to the water so it would know when to shut off.

comment_text: My mother for years of volunteer rehabilitation service was taken out on maneuvers for a ride in a fast surface vessel. She had better security clearance than most and was about the skippers age and gone to school in the same area so spent most of her afternoon in the wheel house talking to the captain 'comparing notes on their highschool years' she said. Eventually he looked over at her and asked "want to see what this thing can do?" She said she did. He sounded off some alarms waited a bit ordered flank speed told her to hang on turned 90°port then 90°starboard. Mom swears if she fell out of her seat she'd have gone over the side. I really appreciated the Deep Dive series, this video in particular. There's something very real and applicable about food for all of us, of course! One of the many things I liked about the Deep Dive series was that individual crew got to tell a bit of their story, and they seem reassured and confident enough about doing so. This is not some standard military PR video. Destin comes across as respectful of the crew and their mission. There's always going to be a bunch of things that won't be public domain on a nuclear submarine, but Destin is straight-up about the things he's not allowed to tell, and allows the crew to tell interesting things. I'm reminded of Stephen Ambrose's (and others) strategy of relying heavily on the folks involved saying things in their own words. Back to my umpteenth viewing of the pizza video now.

comment_by: The Legend in His Own Mind
comment_text: I used to work for a civilian company who loaded pre-ordered food into submarines setting to depart, at the Groton Naval Sub base, where this sub is stationed. You would be amazed at just how many secret compartments for all the various goods are located on board. The most difficult food item to carry from the dock, down a 30 foot vertical hatch, into their freezer, were the 50 lb boxes of frozen steaks; but even those didn't compare to the TD weights. Out at sea, the subs take their garbage, put it into a collapsible cage, and sink it with the weights. They came in these little compact 75 lb boxes. Carry 200 of those straight, and your arms will feel it for a week! 🤣 I don't think the company is around any more. The military is now required to handle their own provisions due to budget cuts. Kinda cool while it lasted though.

Amazing episode, but even more amazing is these men/women working together as a cohesive unit to keep our country safe. We civilians at home appreciate that we have no idea what you go through and the mental tenacity you need to have working in these situations. Stuck in a 250FT tube, 1 mile under water for weeks/months at a time in the middle of BFE. Maybe a few of these guys see daylight when they go topside, but most stay inside for long periods of time. There is no black/white, gender, racial injustice or privialaged. It's brotherhood regardless and each person is critical to their next mates survival regardless of race/affiliations. Everyone has a role to play. Thank you all for your service and doing what you do.

having been in the navy for a very long time,  the only down time, the only enjoyable time, is meal time. everything else is either work, standing watch, or sleeping. Oh, and do not forget the Tabasco Sauce, or Texas Pete. I was never stationed on a sub; but watching this video made me think of the smoke generated by cooking those burgers, or using a deep fryer. Fire is the most feared thing aboard any ship or boat. There is no where to go., which is especially true inside a sub. (just a thought). But lastly, as stated in this video, the "comments" or " complaints" by the crew, regarding the "quality" of food, is taken very very seriously. Good Food=Great Morale=Happy Crew=Smooth Sailing.

I always wondered why you can't grow some food on submarines? I mean sure you probably can't grow large amounts (I mean where would you find the space) but what about even just fresh edible herbs? A lot of herbs grow really quickly, take little space and don't need much besides a little water and a little light. There are many lightweight and mess free plant growth materials too besides the option of growing herbs just in water, the lamps to provide light can also be small compact and lightweight and power shouldn't be a problem with a nuclear reactor, plants will naturally help with eating some carbon dioxide and provide a little more additional oxygen which would be a helpful addition, and you can probably find crooks and crannies all over the sub to attach small planters. One thing I love about watching guys in the military is there so awesome. Everyone is chill and relaxed. No real drama between members. In sure they have their issues like all brothers and sisters. But just the relationship between everyone is amazing to me. Growing up I didn't really know my brothers and sisters because my dad got custody an that was it. I dreamed of being in the military. I was all set up at 16. Recruiters where helping me study the Asvab. I was on schedule to graduate a year early. And then I got in a serious accident that caused serious back problems an wound up with metal rods and screws throughout my body. Just the breaks in my back illuminated my chances. The metal sealed the deal.  I was devastated.  Going from completely independent ready to join the military and everything to codependent in a wheel chair for 2 years while I learned to walk again. it was a bad time. But  I wouldn't trade my life for anything. I got 2 little one's. A good job. Im Studying for computer certifications and Where happy.  But it's still amazing to see. And this video shows it perfectly. They all have a job to do and they do it well. But even its time to relax and just be one of the boys everyone is chill.

I was a cook on that same class boat 25 years ago. So different now. So much pre-made food now. For example, we had a 8lb. block of sausage where we had to make patties by hand not frozen links. We had regular round pizza pans. I made about 75 pizzas. SINGLE HANDEDLY!!! Many specialty by request to order. We put out a meal every six hours, not 8. So while I was doing all those pizzas, I also would be squeezing in anything I could do to be ahead on my regular deserts and breads for the next day's meals. There always seamed to be cookies the next day........
Our shortening, flour, sugar and coffee came in 5 gallon tin cans which were stored under the main engines back aft where I had to climb down into a hole then crawl on my belly for about 15 feet until I reached the larger area where they were all strategically stored then crawl back out with that huge square can. There was no can opener on the boat so the expectation was that we cut it open with a large chef's knife. Eventually, I snuck onboard one of those store bought hand can openers. I wore my dungaree pants, a white tee shirt and the boat's ball cap or an F.S.A. tee shirt. Food on the boat was stored EVERYWHERE!
If we'd had jalapeno poppers on the boat, I would have had to make them from scratch. We did put out wings also on Pizza night. 18 hour shift every day at sea. I was awoken at 5pm and was in the galley in time to help clean up from dinner. Then I put out mid-rats at mid night then breakfast at 6am then I would go to the rack as soon as lunch was put out at 11:30 for some people's early chow. (all meals were ready 30 minutes early for early chow). I'm 55 now but given the chance to do it again, (only for about one 30 day cruise, lol) I WOULD !!!!

I was honestly surprised that they make everything from scratch. I figured considering how the Army is all about their MREs, it just seemed like premade rations and freeze-dried stuff would be the most efficient. But I was thinking about it, and I think the point of MREs and stuff is that you carry it with you and it doesn't matter if it's not frozen and if you don't have access to a freezer or an oven or anything. But in terms of actual physical space, it seems pretty obvious that a bag of flour takes up less space than a bunch of premade pieces of dough or bread. Obviously if you're in hostile territory and are carrying everything you need on your back, it makes sense that you have light and shelf-stable food that you can make without access to a kitchen. But on the sub, you have a freezer, you have a pantry, you have unlimited power, and you have a kitchen, and you take all of that with you everywhere you go. So why wouldn't they make things from scratch?

Pizza night for us was every Saturday night for midrats. Loved it. These guys had a lot more options than we had. Just pizza for us. No mozzarella sticks or jalapeño poppers.

Every Friday we had field day to clean up the boat and afterwards we would have sliders (wimpys or hamburgers). That night for midrats we would have grease cups or hockey pucks which were the leftover hamburgers from earlier that day. They were called that for obvious reasons.

Before betamax we ran movies from a projector to a screen. And movie night was every night with a scheduled flick.

The boat didn't supply any candy. Guys would bring their own snacks or snacks could be purchased from the Recreation Committee.

in 1989 on board USS Henry Clay SSBN 625, we loaded as much food as we could. We had cans on the decks with cardboard over the top so we could walk on them, a packed freezer and refrigerator, and a trim tank filled with coffee and sugar. We did an exercise called COOPEX '89 .. and we did all that load-out in 3 days.

Then we hit the dive point and pulled the plug. We stayed submerged for 118 days. That was my last patrol, my 16th, and my fourth boat.

Yeah, having good food is bare minimum for submarine crews. They don't even get the benefit of long duration space crews being able to look out a window. Their whole existence underway is measured by clocks and meals. No day/night reference, no temperature changes, none of the stuff we take for granted here on the surface. It's very isolated with minimal to no interaction with anyone or anything outside the sub itself. In many ways, these submarines are a good model for how interplanetary trips will be handled once those start happening because of similar levels of isolation. However, again, the deep space voyagers can still see the stars out the window, submariners have no windows. Nothing to see that's not in the submarine.

This is very fun to watch. I was in the Marine infantry for eight years. So, it's fun to see what the rest of the team is up to while we are focused on our mission. The entire military is fascinating. We each have our own methods for tackling the mission.
In the Corps, we didn't have nearly as high quality chow. We mostly ate Meals Ready to Eat, MREs, or Tray Rations, which are steamed trays with prepared meals. On my final tour to Afghanistan, I was embedded as an advisor. That meant only eating Afghan food the whole time. It's all about high fat intake to keep your brain moving while weight falls off the body. I went there 235 and came back 189.
Just different from being on a submarine, that's all. They wouldn't want to walk through minefields. I don't want to be stuck inside with no light underwater for a month at a time.
The U.S. military is the greatest team effort on earth. God bless each and every one of them. Semper fidelis - ALWAYS.

The amount of food on the sub is based on a max number of people. This works in pretty much every in every place that serves food for a X number of people. The one guy said 180 people which I am guessing is the max number while their may be 140 people on board they still serve 180 servings of food.
A 28 day cycle consists of 15120 servings of food. They are required to maintain 30 days of food and my guess is that they maintain 3 cycles of menus at a time.
Making their load of food of about 50k servings of food. If you ball park around 2 pounds of food per serving you will get around 100k pounds of goods including packages.
28 days cycle would consist of a menu that is very simple with a twist. Food! So important. I was a seaman on an 82 foot Coast Guard cutter . We had this bull dog tough as nails ex navy seal for a cook. I once told me all about his why he became a cook. He talked about  living like a beaver in Vietnam and the Coast Guard  would resupply and pick up messages trolling as they  went. The Navy and Army also did these missions.  It's just the Coast Guard left exactly what they asked for and specialties extras like lobster, dungeness and king crab plus lots of fresh vegetables. Guys would pitch in to pay for them. He said if he survived he wanted to be on one of those 82's and well I was on his first after. He was so happy and I really enjoyed his company except when he drank which was nightly. There were times I fetched him at the bar or helped him to his rack after he put his car in the ditch and stumbled back to the boat. You had to be there to understand. I loved this guy although I would imagine he never recovered from Vietnam. I just hope he did and was a dedicated sober chief in a famous Greek restaurant.

I don't think I'd be able to survive this... this year I went on an outdoor environmental science course and the first week, I didn't have a watch at the time, and was constantly super anxious not knowing what time it was for some reason (we weren't allowed our phones so couldn't use that for timekeeping, either). Also felt super jetlagged after the whole ordeal... I promptly bought a watch for the next week. We also did heaps on each day of the week, so I found myself super tired and wondering if we were on our way back to base only to ask my friend what time it was and for her to reply "it's 1 pm". I didn't have that issue anymore when I was a wrist-flick away from knowing the time.
I can't imagine living on a sub and then *only* being able to rely on timekeeping devices, I at least had the sun to give me some kind of an idea what section of the day it was.

There are other factors as well when it comes to veggies.  First off, it's a matter of longevity and space.   Frozen sliced bell peppers is much more space saving than whole fresh ones, and will last much longer.  With a 90 day larder, feeding 140-180 people, that's requires a lot of space, which as you saw is at a total premium in there.  I was surprised that the frozen food wasn't in trays for airflow and getting access.  I know I would have stocked it according to the meal plan, so I'd have easy access for the meal rotations - Monday's meals in trays 1,2,3, and so on.  I would not want to have to "clean the freezer" - ever. Next, there's a much larger opportunity for insects and vermin to get on board with fresh food. Hard to use pesticides on a submarine.  I can't even begin to imagine how these guys can even breathe after working in that space every day.  There ought to be some serious air filtration in that space, as I am sure the gunge would build up quite easily in there. Gunge -  so when people smoke on board, it gets trapped in the moisture in the air. The metal walls are cold, so it condenses, creating a viscous tar-like liquid and can come down the walls and puddle in places. I don't even want to think what that's like on a sub.

I was an aircraft mechanic (AT) but I worked temporarily for 9 months in the aft galley on board CVN-69. It is a common practice for junior enlisted from aircraft squadrons to work T.A.D. for ships company. The food was atrocious, handled with the utmost disrespect for the crews health and most of the cooks couldn't care less about quality. The good ones with integrity almost always worked in the officers mess or the chiefs mess. Food left out for days without refrigeration, frozen food served and mixed in with unfrozen and burned food. CS (culinary specialist) is one of the few jobs in the Navy someone can have a career without a clearance so that is where you get a lot of criminals who took military service over the penitentiary. The aft baker was one of the laziest people I ever saw. Somewhere in leadership they wanted cookies to be put out, most likely to help with crew moral. This baker would only make oatmeal raisin because he knew most people wouldn't eat them and could keep putting out the same batch day after day. They would become hard and gained a real reputation for being terrible, fulfilling the cycle. He could make 200 cookies and they would last a whole week for an enlisted crew of about 2500!

I had a friend who worked in the Admirals galley who would pass out leftovers on occasion and the food was almost the same type but was obviously prepared with care so I know the problem is not the material condition. About 1/2 the food being prepared in the aft galley was not something which is cooked, just heated up with water and served. When I eventually went back to my squadron the sentiment about the galley was the same, that the galley food was nothing to look forward to and often people just ate tuna and crackers from the ships store instead.

Yup, I've never been on a sub. My first question is why they need so many people? Why wouldn't these vessels would do well with 10% of the human manpower, replaced largely by artificial intelligence and robots? Many of the staff do work that wouldn't be necessary if there were fewer humans on board, and with that fall in manpower comes a multiplier effect of less need for space, food, etc. Humans need to sleep, so every job deleted takes two or three humans off the list, plus the multiplier effect of less need for support staff, supplies, and space.

Story from 1984- My boat, the USS Memphis, was on what was supposed to be a 60 day run, when the boat that was supposed to relieve us had a mechanical problem. We ended up being underwater for 91 days straight. Our supply officer had appropriate food for about 70 days- Then we started rationing. The last week all we had left was pancake mix (no syrup) and steak.

Funny postscript was that we stopped in Scotland afterwards- when the crew went ashore, one of the sailors wanted a typical British meal, so he ordered 'crumpets,' not knowing what they were.

He was served pancakes.
That's some good BBQ sauce.
Military cooks are brilliant inovators, they are the butt of a lot of jokes but are greatly appreciated and put most civilian cooks to shame. Respect

As a former food service specialist in the USAF I can attest to the fact that good food is unbelievably important to morale in a confined, controlled environment. Great food = happy, easygoing, productive. Can turn a bad situation into a good or at least a tolerable one.
Bad or mediocre chow = poor performance, pissy moods even open conflicts.
Crazy how important it is.
Just one more thing civilians take for granted and until they've lived through it, will never fully appreciate or understand.
Great video and thanks for shedding some light on the often overlooked and underappreciated Service folks.

Regarding "angles and dangles" on a sub.  Yes, you normally expect smooth sailing and changes in position to happen gradually, therefore are prepared for the changes.  And you train and drill for the unexpected.  Tons and tons of submarine tends to resist sudden change.  But sudden change is a reality of life.  With years underwater I recall only one unforgettable sudden change in my position.  At the time we had no idea what had happened to cause us to have a sudden extreme roll.  Years later it happened to another sub and cause was determined to be a tsunami.  A surface ship on deep water would have just ridden over another unremarkable wave.  Almost all of the energy of a tsunami is under the water.  When that energy wave his us it said HELLO in a large unexpected way.  No idea it was coming but per standard procedures most all  items were stowed and secured.  That does not include the crew which must be able to be mobile constantly.  I found myself immediately looking up at a torpedo above me as I lie on a bulkhead opposite from where I had been standing on deck moments prior.  Thanking the rule books that all those torpedoes were strapped securely where they were held stowed.

I did 6 patrols on the USS Henry Clay 625 Blue crew.  One patrol was part of a "rapid redeployment" exercise where normally you are in port for about 30 days and on patrol for 90.  For this exercise, we did 10 days in port, 110 days on patrol.  We had so much chicken that towards the end of the patrol we had chicken for every meal (including midrats).  And we still had chicken leftover when we pulled back into port.  Great times!!!

Joking aside though; I feel most issues of the crew very very deeply. There's never enough storage space, the freezers are always a mess to navigate and I can compose essays on how every kitchen needs five times more countertops than they're given. There's almost always some sort of shortage or a tool that breaks down or a processor that needs work or knives that get blunt or, oh, I can go on. So props to the cooks for keeping the morale high and the stomachs fed for months on end!

Dear friends watching this video, often times a recurring difficulty on our journey of life is becoming so focused on what we need at the moment that we forget what we already have. I was reminded of that when our church choir sang a beautiful anthem based on Psalm 103. “Bless the Lord, O my soul, and forget not all His benefits” (v. 2 nkjv). The Lord is our forgiver, healer, redeemer, provider, satisfier, and renewer (vv. 4-5). How could we forget that? And yet we often do when the events of daily life shift our attention to pressing needs, recurring failures, and circumstances that seem out of control.

The writer of this psalm calls us to remember, “The Lord is compassionate and gracious...He does not treat us as our sins deserve or repay us according to our iniquities. For as high as the heavens are above the earth, so great is his love for those who fear him” (vv. 8,10-11). By humbling ourselves before God, it opens us up to the blessings of His mercy. In our walk of faith, we come to Jesus Christ humbled by our unworthiness. There is no sense of entitlement as we receive His grace and are overwhelmed by the lavishness of His love.

Never loose sight of the GREAT and AWESOME benefits of acknowledging that you are a sinner in need of our Savior. Confess with your mouth and believe in your heart that Jesus is Lord of your life. Welcome Abba Yahweh (Father God) through Yeshua (Jesus the Christ) into your life. Receive grace by believing in Jesus Christ and what He did on the cross, His death, burial and resurrection for the sins of all mankind. You will then be justified in salvation and blessed with His abundant love by the Holy Spirit! "Praise the Lord, with all your soul; all your inmost being, praise His holy name.”

Please find comfort in praying the following prayer with me...Dear Heavenly Father, we pause to consider all we have in You. Grant us eyes to see Your provision and help us to remember every benefit You have given to us. We honor You, we glorify You and we praise Your Holy Name. In the Mighty name of Your Son, Jesus Christ we thank You, Amen! ❤️❤️❤️

May Father God our Creator bless you in the Glorious name of Jesus Christ our Lord and Savior.

"We can measure time on an atomic clock! Let's call the clock the letter A.
We can synchronize them if we use the A3 clock from which we will count. This clock will stand at an equal distance from both clocks (A1 and A2) and everything is on the same axis and the A3 clock is between A1 and A2 hours. (Scheme A1 A3 A2)
When the calibration signal is sent to A3 to A1 and A2 clocks, we fix the time of its emission on A3 clocks and see when the signal arrives at A1 and A2. We fix the time on the clocks A1 and A2, thus, we find out how long the signal will go to each side. Then, from those hours A, until which the signal went longer, we will send the light source to the receiver clock (the signal to which went faster), let's say the sending clock is the A2 clock, the light will pass through the A3 clock and will also be recorded there and hit for watch A1.
On the A3 clock, we set the time for starting the signal, which will go to the A2 clock and set the light on the A2 clock in motion. After the signal “Start” from the A3 clock, the “Start” command comes to the A2 clock, and after a fixed delay , from the A2 clock the light flies to the A1 clock. When the light passes through the A3 clock, we measure the time on the A3 clock. After the light hits A1, we also fix the time on A1 and send the Light from A1 to A2, through A3. We again fix the time on the A3 and A2 clocks.

After that, if the travel time of Light in one direction coincides with the travel time of Light in the other direction, then the speed of light C is constant in these directions "

On board my submarine, my division was short handed, so we all stood port and starboard watch (6 on/6 off). It was difficult because we had to work and sleep around our eating, watch times, field days, maintenance, showering, etc. The best part about it was that we were always up for every meal (breakfast, lunch, dinner, and mid rats). Fresh baked goods at 2am, first in line for fresh pizza or sliders, etc. And yes, you are right, we gauged our days and nights around meals.  It wasn't Saturday night -- it was pizza night.  It wasn't Monday mid rats - it was Tamale time. Friday Sliders. Everyone always looked forward to Surf and Turf because that marked the midway point of that particular trip out to sea.

Story from 1984- My boat, the USS Memphis, was on what was supposed to be a 60 day run, when the boat that was supposed to relieve us had a mechanical problem. We ended up being underwater for 91 days straight. Our supply officer had appropriate food for about 70 days- Then we started rationing. The last week all we had left was pancake mix (no syrup) and steak.

Funny postscript was that we stopped in Scotland afterwards- when the crew went ashore, one of the sailors wanted a typical British meal, so he ordered 'crumpets,' not knowing what they were.

He was served pancakes.

This is a great series and is a great introduction into what life is like living and working in such a unique field. There are similar experiences that have been covered by more "traditional" style documentary filmmaking but the way you approach it and the enthusiasm that you hold brings such a human element that illuminates the entire experience in a way the traditional documentary misses. It also brings a fascinating question to mind: Have you considered doing this for other unique professions? Just a few I can think of off the top of my head that would make for fascinating episodes would be:
--LifeFlight EMT/air crew
-Firefighter - especially wildfire specialists (such as in California and Australia, though many countries have such specialists - See Mexico sending crews to OR/CA with recent fires)
--Technical Rescue Crew (Technical Rescue is survivor extraction in things like building collapse, major accidents with entrapment, cave-in/collapse, wilderness/ravine falls, etc)
--Science/Mechanical related to LHC/CERN and the potential future of particle physics research with the FCC (Future Circular Collider)
--Go to space and spend time with ISS astronauts. This should be economically viable within 5 years given dramatically decreasing payload costs with Space-X.
--Anything else that you find particularly interesting/fascinating. Regardless of how mundane it may seem at face value, the enthusiasm you bring will make it interesting.

I was on an old sturgeon class boat SSN 680 the Billy Bates. I wish I had a freezer that big, or a chief (cook). My cooks were THE reason officers weren't allowed to carry sidearms anymore. The deep fat fryer can be a risky piece of gear but the cooks are pretty careful with that. I used to make pizza with my cooks, one of the few times I didn't want to kill them.
This video is great. You can't really comprehend how difficult it can be cooking on a submarine. On an SSBN (missile sub) they have a really awesome galley and refrigeration storage system. It's like a palletized deal on rails in a deep fridge. I never served on a boomer but I was jealous of their setup.
Last fun fact. On subs the Supply Officer is called the "chop". This is because staff officers (doctors, lawyers, civil engineers etc) wear a device on their left collar that represents their specialty. The Supply Corps wears an oak leaf (symbol of plenty) but to non-supply types it looks like a pork chop. Pork chop....chop.

I grew up to be an electronics tech and have had the pleasure to work with some of our veterans on simulators for the Navy and Air Force and have learned to appreciate what our armed forces do for us civilians.
So basically you are checking all the boxes for me. Showing me the culmination of the technology, the awesome men and women who run these ships, and the simple pleasures of life that make it real.
I cannot thank you enough for this series.
God bless you and your family my friend.

I've been a CS in the U.S. Coast Guard (I know I know I've heard ALLL the jokes lol but I love it) for a good bit. It's interesting to see the similarities and differences between the Navy and the CG. Like an LT being in charge of ordering and storing all the food. That's completely foreign to me. I'm the one that's in charge of ordering and storing all the provisions and keeping count of everything. I'm also thankful that I have a huge amount of freedom with my menus and I can do a lot of my shopping at normal grocery stores so I don't have to rely on frozen everything. And when they were talking about the descent angle making things tricky I felt it on a spiritual level. Even the biggest CG cutters are smaller than the Navy's smallest ships so they move around a lot. I recently finished a tour on a 154' foot boat with a measly 18' beam. I've had to do pizza night in 10 footers beam-to and the amount of stuff that ends up on the deck is depressing. Mad props to my fellows in the Navy and especially the submariners. I know I couldn't do that for more than a couple weeks. I'll stick to the surface vessels lol.

Also I've spoken to some people that were responsible for designing the galley on the last cutter I was on and I know for a fact that they made sure the dimensions of the galley door would be wide enough to fit a standard full-sized sheet pan through.

The cooks on a submarine are the hardest-working guys onboard. Mad respect. A few things worth pointing out:
1) As the cook calls out "hot tray", everyone gets out of the way. Doesn't matter who it is, a hot tray has higher priority. One person even backed up like 20 feet to clear the way. The passageways on a sub are barely wide enough for one person, so learning when you can go and when you can't is just one of the many things you've gotta learn on a sub.
2) Good food cannot guarantee good morale, but bad food will definitely cause bad morale. It's no wonder the submarine service spends so much effort on high-quality ingredients.
3) Who was bad-mouthing Down Periscope? You come over here and tell that to my FACE! Down Periscope is 100% the most realistic modern submarine movie ever made. Forget Hunt for Red October, forget that K-19 Widowmaker baloney. Down Periscope is 100% accurate, and I can name at least one real person who exactly matches every single character in that movie.

I had a patient come to the ER back in early 2019. He was a cook on a nuclear submarine. He was recently separated from the Navy, and back home working at a bakery that has a Breakfast/Lunch cafe. I asked him what he enjoyed making the most and he said he loved making drumstick ice cream from scratch for everyone on board. He even added the chocolate at the end of the cone!

I think about that our encounter and I enjoy telling his story. I spent his entire ER visit with him. We talked about food and reminisced on past deployments (it was an early Sunday morning and the patient census was low). He truly loved cooking and was eager to update the menu at the bakery/cafe he was working at.

About 3 weeks ago, I took a look at the bakery’s Breakfast/Lunch menu and it is completely revamped. I hope that was a part of his doing and passion. He was someone who was truly remarkable.

When we deployed to Desert Storm, we took on twice the normal supplies we normally take. There was dry goods stacked EVERYWHERE. You couldn't get a sheet of paper in the freezer. But the chow on my ship was top shelf. They always say the best way to keep moral high is thru theirs stomachs, and that's no lie. All the bread was fresh baked every morning. Pies, cakes, fruit...we ate good. Their ships galley was the Blade Cafe. Ours on the Theodore Roosevelt was The San Juan Grill (a take off of San Juan Hill)

The cook is one of the most important people on a sub. Bad food = bad morale = bad crew performance.

I have 9 ex-Navy servicemen and women that work at my company. Two were on subs, all were on boats. They all said the exact same thing. The cook is the most important job on the boat and arguably the most stressful. The captain also uses the cook as a strategic asset, especially for morale. When morale on the boat is low, they will have the cook make up something extra special....pull something from the "special recipe playbook" to boost morale during hard times. They said especially if a large portion of the crew are from a specific geographical area. They will make something ultra specific and regional, barring ingredients, to give morale a shot in the arm. They also said that it is so strategic that the cook will always keep an eye out for these special ingredients at the upcoming ports, to make sure they have their "aces in the hole" ready for when the captain needs it. Whether thats all true or not, I don't know but its a story that they all adhere to. I never realized how important the cooks job was but this video helped reinforce it. Thank you to all the servicemen and women in the US Armed Forces and all our allies around the world.

While there is a huge amount of differences between living and working on a submarine and a deepwater drilling rig, I couldn't help but notice there are a lot of similarities between the two. The twenty four hour a day work schedule, the four meals a day, the accommodations, even the way they cram food into storage spaces is very similar. Even the division of labor between the officers, NCOs and enlisted men are similar to the "company men", "tool pushers" , "drillers", "roughnecks" and "roustabouts". The dangers of being at depth in a submarine or great, especially when you are at war, but the dangers associated with drilling an oil well to 30,000 feet can be just as deadly. Destin, you should see about making a video on a deep water drilling rig in the Gulf of Mexico.

Hey, Destin! I'm a hobbyist baker and this episode got me curious: what altitude does the air on a submarine behave as? I ask because many recipes, particularly breads, can behave quite differently at different altitudes. Also, food tastes "less" in thinner air, because so much of what we think of as taste is really scent-based, and scents travel less well in thin air, which is famously why airplane food is so bad. Not sure you would have learned such a thing, but I figure you could at least attest to your own experience eating while aboard.

It is not the stomach that is the limiting factor. A friend of mine was a Submariner back in the 70s and he told me what the limiting factor was for those boats. 90 days. I was a third cook on the USNS Observation Island. One of the best jobs/experiences of my life. But a cooks life on a ship can be a stressful one. If any other department makes a mistake or screws something up it is forgotten in no time. If a cook screws something up ONCE it is never let down. I ran the Officers mess. So i cooked the captains and all the other officers breakfasts directly daily. It doesn't matter if we were in flat calm seas or 25ft rollers you best get the captains no oil egg white omelet right every time! Sundays were eggs Benedict and that can be a pain in the butt to poach eggs in rough seas when your only heat sources in the o-mess was a steam table and a flattop. I miss the steel beach cookouts on the rear deck. Grilling on huge handmade charcoal grills the engineering department welded up for us. Loaded with steaks and chicken and whatever fish we have caught, while cruising in the pacific. I was honored to be part of one of the last crews to work on that awesome ship before she was decommissioned.

Just putting in my 20 year experience on subs.

The Supply Officer (Chop) is responsible for the food load. It is most often a collateral duty. Even though all that food is loaded onboard, it still doesn't get charged against the ships OPTAR until it is issued. Towards the end of patrol, if the food issue cost is starting to exceed the OPTAR, the Chop will restrict the issue of the costly (good food) and require budget cuts (read that as peanut butter, horsecock, etc.)

Of course, if an inspection team was coming onboard at the end of patrol, the frozen lobster and steak will get issued.

Fresh milk and fresh vegetables usually went away after a couple of weeks, depending on what climate we were deployed to. Powdered milk really sucked. Of course, we had plenty of coffee.

On most of my boats, Friday was pizza night (after Field Day). Each division signed up to make the pizza. Some were great, some were bad, but at least a break from some bad chow.

Oh yeh, the night baker. On some boats, we had a night baker who made the bread for the next day meals. He may also make sticky buns, some of which actually made it to the next day breakfast. Some of them made cakes, but when your oven is sometimes at a 20 degree down bubble, the cakes get a bit slanted.

Enough rememberance.

Step 1
For sauce: Combine all sauce ingredients with 1/2 cup water in a medium bowl; set aside for flavors to develop while making crust. Freeze remaining paste .

Step 2
For crusts: Combine 2 cups of flour with the dry yeast, sugar and salt. Add the water and oil and mix until well blended (about 1 minute). Gradually add enough remaining flour slowly, until a soft, sticky dough ball is formed.

Step 3
Knead for about 4 minutes, on a floured surface, until dough is smooth and elastic. Add more flour, if needed. (If using RapidRise® Yeast, let dough rest, covered, for 10 minutes.)

Step 4
Divide dough in half. Pat each half (with floured hands) into a 12-inch greased pizza pan OR roll dough to fit pans.

Step 5
For pizzas: Preheat oven to 425 degrees F. Top crusts with sauce, pepperoni and cheese.

Step 6
Bake for 18 to 20 minutes until crusts are browned and cheese is bubbly. For best results, rotate pizza pans between top and bottom oven racks halfway through baking.
